prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A whisper in the wind, a ripple on the dew.
You wait in silent corners, in hush between the words,
In quiet contemplation, where honesty is heard.

To listen is to honor the tremble in your tone,
To cradle every syllable, to claim it as my own.
For truth is not a thunder, nor blinding flash of light,
But gentle, patient presence that guides me through the night.

So let me practice silence, let me open up my ear,
Let me greet your subtle wisdom, let me draw you near.
For only in the listening, the careful, steady art,
Can truth be truly spoken, can truth become my heart.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
For words are empty vessels when the heart is not true.
You knock at the door of my conscience, softly, persistently,
Waiting for me to hush my pride, to hear you consistently.

You dwell not in the clamor, but in the gentle pause,
In the spaces between questions, in the spirit’s cause.
To speak you is to know you, to know you is to hear,
The subtle, quiet wisdom that only draws near
When I am humble, patient, and willing to receive—
Truth, you are the gift I give when I believe.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A melody woven in the silence, a dawn breaking through.
You arrive on tiptoe, unadorned and clear,
Waiting for me to quiet my doubts and hear.

Not in the thunder of certainty, but in the gentle rain,
You teach me to sit with discomfort, to bear the pain.
For only when I listen, with an open, steady mind,
Can I hope to speak you, honest and kind.

Let me cultivate the habit, let me tend to the ear,
So that truth may blossom, and its voice I may hear.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not just in daylight’s certainty, but in the midnight blue.
You do not shout above the crowd, nor clamor for my praise,
You linger in the quiet hours, in gentle, honest ways.

If I learn to still my racing mind, to listen and to wait,
Perhaps I’ll hear your quiet song, your voice behind the gate.
For only then can I repeat your message, clear and bright,
If I have learned to listen well, and honor what is right.

So let me build the habit, let me practice every day,
And truth, I shall speak you, in my words and in my way.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
You are not always comfortable, nor always easy to pursue.
You dwell in silent spaces, in questions left unasked,
In the patience of reflection, in the courage of the task.

To listen is to labor, to dig beneath the skin,
To wait for your arrival, to welcome you within.
If I would speak you clearly, let me first attend,
To the voice within the silence, to the message you send.

Let me be a vessel, let me hear your gentle call,
So when I speak, it’s truly you, and not my pride at all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
This anger burns deep within,
A silent fire beneath my skin.
It flickers in the midnight gloom,
A shadow dancing in my room.

I try to cage it, calm the blaze,
But embers smolder through the haze.
Each word unsaid, each slight ignored,
Becomes a spark my soul has stored.

I walk with fury, masked and veiled,
A tempest bottled, never quelled.
Yet in the heat, I find my voice,
To shape my pain, to make my choice.

For though this anger sears my core,
It carves a path not known before.
From burning coals, I rise anew—
Forged by the fire, fierce and true.

This anger burns deep within,
Molten rivers beneath my skin.
A silent scream, a thunder’s call,
Echoing through each battered wall.

It pulses, red and raw and bright,
A beacon in the endless night.
Unspoken words and bitter fears,
Distilled in salt of hidden tears.

But in the heat, I find resolve,
A promise that I will evolve.
For from this fire, I will create
A future free from wrath and hate.

Let anger be my guiding star,
Transforming wounds into memoir.

This anger burns deep within,
A storm where hope and hurt begin.
It coils around my fragile heart,
Refusing ever to depart.

It colors every word I say,
Turns gentle light to ashen gray.
Yet in its heat, I feel alive,
A force that helps me to survive.

I channel rage into my art,
Let fury fuel a brand new start.
For from this blaze, I rise, I mend—
A soul reborn, a firebrand friend.

This anger burns deep within,
A secret kept beneath my grin.
It simmers low, a quiet ache,
A longing for the world to wake.

Each slight, each wound, each careless word,
Becomes a flame, too long unheard.
Yet as it grows, I find the means
To turn the fire into dreams.

From ashes, new resolve is spun,
A will to fight, a race to run.
Though anger scorches, leaves its mark,
It lights the way through all the dark.

This anger burns deep within,
A furnace forged of ancient sin.
It smolders, waiting to ignite,
A beacon in the darkest night.

With every breath, the embers grow,
Fed by the things I can’t let go.
Yet in the blaze, I sense a shift—
A strength, a hope, a precious gift.

For anger, when it’s understood,
Can shape the bad and birth the good.
So let this fire inside me spin,
And light the world from deep within.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
War's a joke for me and you,
A jest we tell when skies are blue,
We laugh at tales of cannon fire,
Of heroes bold and funeral pyre.

We trade in stories, safe and warm,
No mud upon our boots or harm,
No rattle in our trembling hands,
No trenches carved in distant lands.

Yet somewhere, someone bears the brunt,
Of every punchline, every stunt.
For us, it's words—a fleeting game;
For them, it's blood and loss and shame.

So let us pause before we jest,
And hold the laughter in our chest.
For war may seem a joke to two,
But not to those who live it through.

War's a joke for me and you,
A punchline tossed in crowded rooms,
Where laughter shields us from the truth,
And innocence resumes.

We sip our tea, we share our memes,
The horror distant as a dream,
But echoes linger in the dark,
Of lives undone by war's cruel spark.

We jest and jibe, the headlines fade,
The world a stage, our roles well-played,
Yet somewhere, sorrow breaks anew—
War's no joke for them, or you.

War's a joke for me and you,
From distant chairs, the battle's through.
We sketch our soldiers, neat and small,
And never fear the bugle's call.

We turn the news to black and white,
A comic strip, a barroom fight.
But laughter cracks when stories end,
And silence falls where once was friend.

We count our blessings, safe and free,
For war's a joke—at least for me.
But let us not forget the cost,
The punchline paid by all we've lost.

War's a joke for me and you,
We trade the tales as if they're true,
With clever words and knowing grins,
Unburdened by the world that spins.

We mock the chaos, turn away,
Pretend it's far, another day.
Yet somewhere, mothers clutch the air,
And fathers weep in silent prayer.

So let us not with laughter blind,
The suffering of humankind.
For war, a joke, may seem to be,
But costs too much for you and me.

War's a joke for me and you,
Safe behind the evening news,
We watch the footage, shake our heads,
And tuck our children into beds.

We speak of valor, loss, and pride,
But never feel the loss inside.
For us, it's history, not pain,
A fleeting shadow, not the rain.

Yet somewhere, someone cannot sleep,
Their memories cut far too deep.
So war may seem a jest, it's true,
But only for the lucky few.

Yet in that wild and haunted, searching look,

He looks at me, and in his madness, cries

He looks at me with a madman's eyes—
A flicker of chaos, a world in demise.
His stare is a labyrinth, twisted and deep,

His laughter is brittle, sharp as a blade,

Yet in that wild gaze, a story unfolds,

He looks at me with a madman’s despair,

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That dances in the waking light,
For laughter ringing, pure and buoyed,
And stars that shimmer through the night.

For petals opening to the sun,
For gentle words, for hearts that sing,
For every moment just begun,
And hope that blooms with every spring.

Blessed be Thou for smiles unseen,
For kindness flowing, soft and deep,
For dreams that color all between,
And solace found within our sleep.

So let me offer thanks anew,
For gifts that time cannot destroy,
With every breath, my soul is true:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That spills upon the morning dew,
For every song that hearts employ,
And every sky of boundless blue.

For laughter shared in candlelight,
For peace that settles on the soul,
For friendships glowing warm and bright,
And love that gently makes us whole.

O source of wonder, grace, and mirth,
Who plants the seed of every smile,
May gratitude adorn the earth
And carry us through every trial.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For all the light, the hope, the grace—
In every moment we employ,
Your blessings fill this sacred space.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That glimmers in a child’s eye,
For whispered dreams we dare employ,
And courage when we’re asked to try.

For sunbeams painting golden hours,
For music drifting on the breeze,
For gardens blooming into flowers,
And quiet moments such as these.

O thankfulness that overflows,
A river deep, a boundless sea,
With every breath my spirit knows
The joy that flows from Thee to me.

Blessed be Thou, whose gifts abound,
In every laugh, in every sigh,
For in Your love, true joy is found—
Blessed be Thou, forever nigh.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That lingers softly in the air,
For fleeting moments we employ
To show we love, to hope, to care.

For gentle rain on thirsty earth,
For morning’s hush, for evening’s peace,
For every gentle, quiet birth
Of happiness that will not cease.

O Giver of the purest light,
Who fills our hearts and lifts our gaze,
Let gratitude be our delight
As we recount these joyful days.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For every gift, both small and grand,
May thankfulness our lips employ,
And praise resound across the land.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That weaves through shadows, fierce and bright,
For every tear that finds alloy
In laughter’s gold, in hope’s delight.

For hands that hold, for words that heal,
For silent strength that walks beside,
For moments when our spirits kneel
In awe, with gratitude our guide.

Each sunrise paints a hymn anew,
Each sunset folds the day with grace,
Blessed be Thou, who sees us through,
Who fills with light the darkest place.

For every joy, both loud and small,
My heart lifts up a thankful cry:
Blessed be Thou, the source of all,
Who gifts us wings with which to fly.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text:
On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
A storm of justice in His hand, a voice the world could not ignore.
He strode across the broken land where silence masked the cries,
And cut the veils of falsehood down with fire in His eyes.

Not gentle words, nor soft embrace, but truth that burned away
the shadows lurking in the hearts that wandered far astray.
He called the timid and the bold to choose a side that day,
For peace that rests on lies alone, He would not let it stay.

The sword He bore was not of steel, but sharper, forged of light—
It split the night from dawning hope, the wrong from what is right.
So tremble not at thunder’s roll, nor at the clash of swords,
For sometimes peace is born anew when truth divides the world.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
He cleaved the silence of the age, the hearts that slept, the minds that warred.
No olive branch, no gentle dove, but lightning in His stride,
He spoke in riddles, parables, with justice as His guide.

He cut through comfort’s velvet veil, revealed the hidden pain,
Unmasking all hypocrisy, exposing every stain.
His sword was not for flesh and bone, but for the soul’s release,
To set aflame the stagnant hearts and offer truer peace.

He turned the tables, broke the chains, and called the world to see:
The sword of truth divides the night, to set the captives free.
So let His fire forge your path, and let your spirit soar,
For Christ The Lord has come anew—not with peace, but with a sword.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
He shattered chains and ancient lies that comfort had ignored.
A harbinger of holy change, He challenged every throne,
And called the meek and mighty both to stand or stand alone.

The sword He bore was not of steel, but truth that cleaves the night,
It cut through pride and prejudice, revealing wrong and right.
The world, expecting gentle words, was startled by the flame
Of justice, mercy, sacrifice—He called us each by name.

So let us not mistake His call for quiet, easy days,
But rather for the courage found in walking in His ways.
On the scene came Christ The Lord, dividing dark from light—
He bids us choose, to stand for love, and join Him in the fight.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
He drew a line through ancient ways, a challenge to the horde.
The quiet fields, the bustling streets, all trembled at His word,
For He had come to stir the soul, not let it go unheard.

He split the darkness with His fire, He broke the silent code,
Unveiling all that must be changed, the burdens we had towed.
His sword was forged of justice, fierce, its edge was bright and keen,
It called the weary to awake, to see what might have been.

Not comfort, but conviction’s call, He offered to the crowd,
A path of courage, sacrifice, and standing strong and proud.
On the scene came Christ The Lord, a force none could ignore—
He brought the dawn, and with His sword, He opened up the door.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
He came to rend the veils apart, to pierce the hearts that soared
on wings of easy certitude, on lullabies of old.
He came to draw the battle lines where comfort had grown cold.

No gentle lull, no whispered balm, but fire in His eyes—
He beckoned those who dared to see through every thin disguise.
The sword He bore was not of steel, but words that split the night,
Dividing truth from cherished lies, exposing wrong and right.

He called the world to reckon with the cost of being free:
To choose the narrow, thorny path and bear His mystery.
On the scene came Christ The Lord, His purpose clear and strong—
To wake us from our restless peace, and right what had gone wrong.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
In silent dawn, my soul has known  
A yearning deep, a whisper clear,  
That draws me ever, ever near.  

No idol voice, no fleeting shade  
Can fill the ache Thy love has made.  
In desert lands, my spirit thirsts,  
Yet in Thy arms, my heart finds firsts—  

First light, first hope, first song to sing,  
First joy that makes the desert spring.  
All else may fade, all else may roam,  
But Thou, my God, my heart, my home.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
No other voice can claim the throne  
Within the chambers of my heart,  
Where sacred longing sets apart  
A place for Thee, and Thee alone.  

Through storm and silence, joy and moan,  
My soul returns, a homing dove,  
To rest within Thy boundless love.  
Let earth and heaven fade away—  
Still, Thou art God, my light, my stay.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
The stars bear witness as I groan  
For comfort in the midnight hour,  
A touch of grace, a breath of power.  

No earthly friend, nor golden throne,  
Can answer prayers that I intone.  
In solitude, my spirit cries,  
And finds its peace beyond the skies.  

My heart, Thy temple, set apart—  
O God, my God, possess my heart.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
No echo fills Thy sacred tone.  
Through valleys low and mountains high,  
My faith in Thee will never die.  

In morning's hush and evening's gloom,  
Thy presence fills my every room.  
No riches, fame, nor fleeting praise  
Can turn my heart from Thee, always.  

My soul’s delight, my guiding sun—  
O God, my God, Thou art the One.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
In every breath, in every bone,  
I sense Thy nearness, ever true,  
A love the world could never rue.  

When shadows fall and hope is thin,  
Thy gentle voice calls me within.  
No power, no prince, no fleeting light  
Can steal my soul from Thee this night.  

Forevermore, my praise shall be—  
O God, my God, abide with me.

Rewind life and remember

The first time we stumbled, the last time we ran,

Rewind life and remember

Rewind life and remember—

Rewind life and remember—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
My eyes trained low, my voice a hush,
Hands muddied by the earth I clung,
Afraid to break the brittle hush.

I wore the dust upon my skin,
A second layer, thick and tight,
Hoping no gaze would wander in,
To glimpse the tremor of my fright.

Yet dawn arrived with open arms,
A gentle light, a subtle call;
It beckoned me from fearsome charms,
And showed me how to stand, not crawl.

Now I walk, no longer bowed,
A memory of soil behind,
For I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I lift my face to find—the sky.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Hunched beneath the weight of want,
My shadow curling in the dust,
Dreams dissolving, pale and gaunt.

The world above was far and bright,
A sun I dared not hope to reach;
My voice was lost, my wings were tight,
My heart, a stone upon the beach.

But somewhere in the silent dark,
A spark survived, a stubborn gleam;
It whispered softly, left a mark,
It painted hope into my dream.

Now, risen from the crawling earth,
I walk with dignity and grace;
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I meet the world, face to face.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through the tangled weeds,
My spirit battered, hope a dunce,
My hunger gnawing at my needs.

The sky was just a rumor then,
A distant blue I could not touch,
My world confined to muddy dens,
My longing felt, but never much.

But somewhere in the muck and mire,
A single blade of grass stood tall;
I watched it sway, I felt desire,
To rise, to stand, to heed the call.

Now, upright in the golden sun,
I stretch and breathe, no longer small;
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I walk, and sometimes—run.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Clutching scraps of borrowed light,
My voice a whisper, barely heard,
My days dissolving into night.

I hid beneath the heavy stones
Of shame and silence, cold and deep,
Afraid to claim a name my own,
Afraid to wake from fitful sleep.

Yet in the darkness, roots took hold,
A fragile strength began to grow;
A trembling hope, a story told
Of what the buried seeds might know.

Now I rise on trembling feet,
A creature learning how to be,
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I claim my liberty.

I was a grovelling creature once,
My back bent low by unseen chains,
The world above a distant dance,
My hands grown numb with phantom pains.

Each day a struggle to survive,
Each night a prayer for something more,
I watched the winged and envied flight,
Yet feared the cost of leaving floor.

But time, relentless, cracks the shell,
And hunger grows for sky and sun;
A voice within begins to swell,
A promise whispered: you are one.

Now, upright, gaze unshackled, clear,
I greet the dawn with open eyes;
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I rise, and rise, and rise.

My hands were mud, my hopes were stone,
The world above a distant sky,
I wore the weight of every groan,
And never learned to question why.

But dawn, relentless, pierced my shell,
Its golden blade a gentle shove,
And I, who once in darkness fell,
Rose on the wings of self and love.

Now, when the earth calls me to kneel,
I stand and let the sunlight heal.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Beneath the weight of empty skies,
My dreams were dust, my hopes askew,
Afraid to meet the morning’s eyes.

But time, that ancient alchemist,
Stirred embers in my weary chest;
From trembling knees I learned to rise,
To seek, to stumble, and to quest.

Now, though the shadows sometimes call,
I walk with footprints bold and free;
No longer earthbound by my fears—
A creature grown, becoming me.

I was a grovelling creature once,
My voice a whisper in the mire,
Each day a chain, each hope a dunce,
Each longing lost to muck and fire.

Yet somewhere in the silence deep,
A spark endured, a fragile gleam,
It taught my battered soul to leap,
To chase the outline of a dream.

Now upright, with a steady gaze,
I meet the world and all its scars,
A memory of darker days
Transformed beneath forgiving stars.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Afraid to lift my gaze above the ground,
My voice a hush, my spirit hunched,
A shadow trailing, barely making sound.

But even worms will yearn for wings,
And seeds will split to greet the sun,
So from the muck my courage springs,
And what was lost becomes begun.

Now, with trembling steps I rise,
No longer shamed by where I’ve been,
A creature learning how to fly,
Forgiven, fierce, and born again.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Hunched in the hollow of my fear,
A ghost of hope, a crumpled want,
Invisible, unheard, unclear.

But seasons shift and rivers bend,
And rain will carve the hardest stone,
So inch by inch, I learned to mend,
To claim the courage as my own.

Now, standing tall where shadows fell,
I see the sky, I taste the air,
And though the past still weaves its spell,
I am a creature climbing there.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Beneath the weight of silent moons,
Crawling through the shadowed months,
Dreaming of sunlit afternoons.

My hands were calloused, knees were raw,
My voice a whisper in the mire,
Yet hope, a flicker, found its law
And coaxed my spirit to aspire.

Now I stand, no longer bowed,
A witness to my own rebirth;
I shed the skin, I speak aloud—
I am the architect of earth.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Face pressed to the trembling ground,
Fingers clawing at the dust,
Afraid of every subtle sound.

I measured worth in crumbs and fear,
In shadows cast by distant light,
But somewhere hope began to steer
My trembling soul toward the right.

Now I rise, unshackled, free,
A voice that dares to shape its fate;
I leave behind that memory,
And walk unbowed through every gate.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Hunched beneath a world of stone,
Hiding from the piercing suns,
Afraid to claim a life my own.

But time is patient, slow and sure,
It whispers courage in the cracks,
And teaches wounds how to endure,
To mend the spine that sorrow lacks.

Now I stretch toward morning’s grace,
No longer fettered by the past,
I meet the dawn with upturned face,
A creature risen, free at last.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Blind to the color of the sky,
My words were dust, my dreams askew,
My only wish: to not ask why.

But storms will churn the stagnant pool,
And thunder shakes the deepest root;
I learned to stand, to break the rule,
To lift my gaze and taste the fruit.

No longer do I crawl in fear—
I sing, I leap, I dare to dance;
For from the mud, a soul grew clear,
And found its voice, and took its chance.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow lost beneath the stars,
Bound by invisible response
To wounds that left their silent scars.

But dawn is patient, day is kind,
And in the hush before the light,
I found the courage to unwind
The chains that bound me through the night.

Now I rise on trembling legs,
A pilgrim of the open air;
From dust and darkness, hope now begs
A song, a promise, and a prayer.

People are happy, and hope fills the heart.

People are happy, the world softly spins,
Joy found in moments, in losses and wins.
Picnics and daydreams, a song in the air,
Kind words exchanged with a smile to spare.

People are happy, or learning to be,
Finding small wonders in all that they see.
Sunflowers turning their heads to the sun,
Reminding us all that we’re never alone.

People are happy, their laughter rings clear,
Bridging the distance, dissolving the fear.
A chorus of gladness, a world full of light—
People are happy, and all feels right.
